39356394.review:
An RPG game that you can beat in a weekend for only $3? Sounds like a sweet deal... but is it? Let's find out.


[u]The Good:[/u]

Taking a long hard look at Crystal Story 2 and reviewing the content that it provides, it’s surprising to see what is presented here.

Consider the following: A good length for story with post game content as well, an easy to follow battle setup with a level up system familiar to Final Fantasy X, a variety of mini-games & side-quests provided and finally, if Crystal Story 2 wasn’t enough, you can also find the original game, Crystal Story, packaged as well for those that are curious.

And all this is provided for only $3. If this isn’t a done deal, then I don’t know what will talk you into buying a game.


[u]The Bad:[/u]

As mentioned in the previous section, Crystal Story 2 has a level up system that is familiar to the one used in Final Fantasy X, which is setup as a sphere grid. Here, you have the grids setup in a linear path and broken up in different classes for variety. where you spend the experience gained to enhance your stats and learn new skills.

While this is setup neatly and easy to follow, it’s also guilty in making the game easy. On one hand, you could blame that on the abundance of experience that you can receive through both the main story and completing side-quests. On the other hand, because a few classes strengthen a specific area, it makes it easy for the player to choose which class to focus on for the specific character.


[u]The Ugly:[/u]

At times, Crystal Story suffers from a few audio issues. It’s not an issue that can be fixed by adjusting in the options, because it’s in relation to the specific audio files, where some clips sound louder than others.



If it wasn’t clear in the Good section, the low value to this game is half the reason why I recommend this game. The other half would be the fact that this is a decent game. If you have change available and are looking for a good game, give Crystal Story 2 a shot.

34895074.review:
This is one of those fairly simple turn-based RPG games, So rather than describe what I thought of the game I'll instead describe what I liked about the game in terms of mechanics/content/Etc that differentiated this from other games I've played in the past.

Just to clarify I have beaten this game in the past, However it was on the flash version of the game. So ignore my steam hours.


The take on the speed mechanic was a big one. I like the fact that it wasn't just a basic number to decide who moves first. The intervals in which your character can perform actions I find works out better than having it affixed to something like dodge rate/Your character's ability to attack multiple times on their turn. Really this was one of the sticking points that kept me playing the flash version. Child of Light is the only game I have played since that has used a refined version of this same speed system.

The option to use the numpad rather than a standard mouse/keyboard was another big thing. There's nothing wrong with the standard mouse/keyboard set-up, But I find as progress farther into the game (Especially my old craptop with a touch pad that won't function if you're using the keyboard at the same time) it's more efficient to utilize the key bindings for all of your actions. You still need to use your mouse for trivial things like sorting your inventory/Equipping gear on characters/etc, But overall you can get away with the numpad for just about everything.

Then there are the completely random minigames thrown all over the place. They are rather basic, But they add some sort of charm to the game. I've never found them to be repetitive, They're short enough to be satisfying without overstaying their welcome.

The only thing I dislike about this game is the fact that the enemy bestiary is rather lacking. Enemy resistances to spell damage/effects doesn't seem to be specified, And actually finding the information on the enemy is somewhat hidden and you would need to scour across most of the entries to find the one you're looking for.

Overall the actual combat/Story progression is about what you'd expect.I did end up buying this during the Summer Sale, But I would have paid full price. It's a fairly cheap game and anyone should be able to get at least a few hours out of it.

I've actually meant to write a review for this game for quite some time now. 

At first I was mischievious because the game wasn't expensive at all in the first place and I bought it during a steam sale. It didn't exactly look professionally made too but I really wanted to give it a try. 

At first I was a little bit disappointed because the battles weren't really hard at the beginning. It stayed that way for a long time - like until the fourth chapter or so - but it gets a little bit harder in the end. That and a lot of other possibilities during the game fully compensate for the fact that the battle system lacks depth. The developer made an attempt in implementing a crafting system, fighter classes and skills that weren't all bad too. 

There are minigames like snowboarding, fishing, some kind of tower defense, a match-3 game, a card game and so on and so forth. Mostly the minigames fit into the game or are just a nice feature. The only thing being a little bit out of place was the pet you got and that you could dress with stuff you got with successfully fullfilling your quests. [spoiler] I laughed out loud when I first used the pet in a fight and it just burried my foes.[/spoiler]

The story isn't really fleshed out too. You can't really think about something, there aren't that many emotions, the characters won't grow on you and it's really not that memorable. The background music was getting on my nervers after a while too.

The art was mediocre but I liked it. It complemented the overall-style of the game. 

Despite all the negative points I must say that I liked the game. It was a good play and I'm not even fully done yet. You get a hell lot out of relatively speaking little money. Don't play it with way to high expectations and I'm sure you'll enjoy it too.

29429291.review:
[b]Crystall Story II [/b] ist ein klassisches RPG in einem eher minimalistischen Grafikstil.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Das Gameplay von Crystall Story II beschreitet keine neuen Wege. Gekämpft wird in einem Rundenbasierenden SideviewKampfsystem mit ATB (Active Time Battle) Leiste. Also kein Statisches Rundenkampfsystem mit fester Zugreihenfolge. Unüblich aber bereits bekannt ist, dass es keine LevelUPs gibt. Man erlangt nach jedem Kampf Skillpunkte, die man in einen der 6 verschiedenen (recht geradlinig aufgebauten) Klassenbäume investiert, die hier und da die Wahl zwischen zwei Upgradeoptionen lassen, die aber eher in der Masse als für sich einen Unterschied machen.

Eine weitere personalisierungsmöglichkeit der bis zu vier Helden besteht im Ausrüsten unterschiedlichem Equipments. Jedem Helden stehen eine Vielzahl an Waffen zur Verfügung, die unterschiedliche Attribute erhöhen oder andere Boni wie Lebensraub mit sich bringen. Leider bekommt man erst eher spät im Spiel wirklich die Möglichkeit, sich wirklich zu entscheiden, da diese Waffen entweder gecraftet oder gefunden werden müssen.

Stichwort Crafting. Das Craftingsystem im Spiel ist zwar vom Aufbau her einfach aber von der Umsetzung her eher umständlich gehalten, da man viele für bestimmte Items nötige Zutaten eher spät bekommt oder sich erfarmen muss, was in anbetracht des Schwierigkeitsgrades der Kämpfe im Spiel eher unmotivierend ist, Eine Möglichkeit, einige später zu kaufen gibt es zwar, aber nur die allgemeinen, die man wirklich in großer Zahl braucht. Alles in allem wird das System erst vergleichsweise Spät im Spiel wirklich bedeutsam.

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad der Kämpfe ist bis zum Lategame extrem niedrig. Viele Gegner und sogar Bosse kommen bisweilen nichteinmal zum Zug, bevor sie besiegt sind. Erst die letzten Bosse der Story, die meisten der [X]-Versionen der optionalen Bosse und die speziell fürs Endgame vorgesehenen optionalen Bosse kann man wirklich auch als Bosse betrachten, einige sind sogar stark Genug, um die Gruppe ohne ordentliches Equipment auf einen Schlag zu besiegen. Hier ist dann massives Grinding und Ausskillen aller Klassenbäume bei jedem Charakter gefragt sowie das Upgraden aller Ausrüstungsteile aufs Maximum. Das sind allerdings nur die Optionalen Bosse. Die Handlung lässt sich recht einfach durchspielen.

Ein großes Manko sind die Dungeons, die einfach nur eintönig und leer wirken.

[b]Grafik, Soundtrack[/b]
Ich habe keine Ahnung, was einige Reviewer gegen die Grafik haben. Die Grafik ist minimalistisch und Cartoonhaft, allerdings passt dies recht gut zum Spiel, da es sich insgesammt wenig ernst nimmt.

Der Soundtrack ist gut gelungen.

[b]Zusammenfassung[/b]
Pro:
[list]
    [*]Nette Grafik, passend zur Stimmung im Spiel
    [*]Guter Soundtrack
    [*]Gegen Ende fordernde Bosse
    [*]Minigames
[/list]

Kontra:
[list]
    [*]Eintönige, teils zu lange Dungeons
    [*]Das Craftingsystem hätte besser umgesetzt sein können
[/list]

[b]Fazit:[/b]
Alles in Allem erfindet Crystall Story II das Rad nicht neu, ist aber trotz einiger Schönheitsfehler ein solides (wenn auch großteils zu leichtes) RPG für zwischendurch. Wer eine tiefe, ernsthafte Story mit Komplexen Charakteren sucht, wird hier allerdings enttäuscht. Wer jedoch einfach nur mal etwas zocken möchte oder erste Erfahrungen, im JRPG Genre sammeln will, der kann hier ruhig zugreifen.

"TUNNELS SNAKES RULE!"

26512870.review:
Crystal Story II is freaking amazing.

A grand RPG that pays tribute to the JRPG genre. 
The story is slightly sub-par if you haven't had the pleasure of playing the first one (link included at bottom of review).
The art isn't amazing, but it is worth your money.

Summary of Crystal Story II.
"Crystal Story II is a role-playing flash game created by Emmanuel Salva Cruz. It uses a turn-based battle system where the player battles using 1-4 characters against a number of enemies. In the game, the player completes quests as they travel through locations, accessible through a world map, with randomly generated layouts. As the player makes their way through locations they unlock more locations and side-quests. The game follows the adventure of D, a dragon who is sent to stop the evil witch Rita from releasing the Dargons into the world. Along the way, D gains several allies including Lina, Mari, and Kaz who help him to complete his quest." ( "Crystal Story II: War of the Shattered Sky | Wikia." Crystal Story II Wiki, crystal-story-ii.wikia.com/wiki/Crystal_Story_II:_War_of_the_Shattered_Sky. Accessed 9 Nov. 2016)

Without further BSing, Your pros + Cons
 
1: Enjoyable story.
2: Warm inviting feel to the game.
3: Nice art for an indie project.
4: Classes aren't character locked
     Ex. you can have Slayer I - Healer I - Guardian II - Healer II - Elementarist III - etc., if that's what you want.
5: Fun Minigames. I mean fun minigames.
     Ex. A bejewled-esque zombie killing event, and your overly-complicated lockpicking game.
6: Good music for an indie game.
7: Insanely reasonable price, especially since the game gives nearly 95+ hours of gameplay (or I must really suck at it)
9: You can play the game entirely with your keyboard if you have no mouse

Cons.
1: A low price for such a good game almost makes me feel like I'm stealing it.
2: A crapload of grinding is required for before Rita.
3: You'll spend so much time trying to have the cutest slime pet.
4: In the end you have to spend a F***load of gold to buy weapons to turn to scrap to upgrade your endgame gear.
5: AGI stat based combat turns.


In conclusion, this game is amazing, and worth way more than $2.99 american.

Link to Crystal Story on Kongregate http://www.kongregate.com/games/lan14n/crystal-story?acomplete=crystal+story
Link to the Creator's website http://emmanuelsalvacruz.com/   (he's working on a new game, I'd suggest checking it out)

With love, Xerrif & Wolf Striker

26308182.review:
Where to begin... 
This game is parody. Parody on A+ titles, in almost everything - graphics, which looks like MS Paint crosbreeded with RPG Maker, cliché story... But, and the word but should be written with BIG letters, this game surpasses many of today's A+ titles in gameplay and content. Bold statement? Definitely!
Little explanation for those who doubt. At first, it's the leveling system. Instead of EXP, you get skillpoints (SP), and you use them for upgrading your characters in the way you like. Next is crafting system - it works. You can make items, and most importantly, level them and thus increase their statistics. Simple, and throughout story progress more and more important. Last, but not least, are the minigames. Here is something, in which Crystal Story II surpasses most of the games published these days. Tower defense? Check. Card game? Check. Fishing simulator? Hell yes! Oh, and some snowboard racing done in retro style. All these minigames offers more enjoyment than games, which are constantly spamming my EXPLORE que. And are part of indie RPG, bought for almost nothing.
Conclusion - pleasant surpise for few bucks. Creators of this game,  thank you. Good job!

24995715.review: I got this game while it was on sale in a bundle with another indie RPG for a dollar or two. In all honesty I didn't think I'd ever play it very much if at all, but I wasn't going to use that amount of money for anything else. So to say that I was pleasantly surprised when I started to play is an understatement. The gameplay itself is fine, although not spectacular. It uses a combat style similar to games like Child of Light, where a bar on the side of the screen builds to your party's actions as well as the enemy's, making it possible to time stuns perfectly for heals. Overall it's not super difficult but you will need to be careful still, as a few bosses surprised me, but at no point did I feel the need to grind or like the enemies were overpowered, more so some being a bit too weak but nothing bad. The leveling system is similar to the FFXIII games, where you use points earned from battle to upgrade your character's stats and learn skills, giving you options for your branches after completing each one, meaning you can make any of your characters into anything you wish. The battle arena is a nice way to get these points easily as well as quite a bit of gold and useful items. The Achemy and Forging add even more depth to a surprisingly refined game for the price. The card game is enjoyable but simple, providing a distraction if you want a break from the battling. The lockpicking of chests is a nice little minigame, the Zombie Defense minigames are nice too. The fishing is also a good addition. Overall there is plenty to do, and if you get bored of the minigames or main quests you can accept quests from the Taverns for more gold, items, experience and new areas to explore. I seriously recommend this game to any RPG fan or anyone who'd like to try an RPG that isn't Triple A or mainstream, I got it for 1$ in a bundle and to be honest I'd have payed more for it having played it now. Wonderful game, had fun all the way through.

24091224.review:
After 70+ hours and unlocking every achievement, I can honestly say that I loved this game.

It has so-so graphics, "eh" voice acting, and an okay soundtrack. The plot was fairly generic.

So how is this game so gosh-darn fun? Well, it doesn't take itself seriously. It was well-written without being groundbreaking, and easy to understand. It was challenging for me to win every achievement but easy for me to beat the main story, making it a great game for anyone--people of all talents and ages. Moreover, the writing draws you into the story and makes you feel a cheerful excitement and attachment for the main characters. Lastly, the art for the everpresent RPG slimes was adorable.

22752017.review:
A surprising amount to this game considering the price.


A fairly traditional J-RPG, with a turn-based / ATB mix system similar to Grandia, where the time bar fills up, and time pauses when a character reaches the action stage, allowing you to enter a command.

The Level up system is like Final Fantasy 13's EXCEPT with a lot more freedom & customisation; instead of levelling up, you earn skill points that you spend on a series of skill trees. You pick one of (trying to remember the number...) ~6 classes, which each gives different stat bonuses & moves, depending on the character in question. Once you complete the path of ~25 'nodes' you can pick another class to continue on. After completing 2 classes, you then pick from the original group again, except the classes are now Rank 2, and have new stat & skill rewards for the tree.
Also, every fifth or so node will give you the choice between 1 of 2 rewards, so you can actually vastly change your party as time goes on - I had one character receiving only Attack & HP boosts to the best of my ability, leaving a slow and powerful guy who's next to impossible to kill; I also made 2 characters focus on All-hitting attacks with high speed, so they can continually barrage the enemies with solid amounts of damage. The 4th character I focused on a range of magic abilities, so that powerful healing and damage could be carried out against more physically-oriented enemies.


Enemies roam about on the field map, the standard 'don't want to battle, don't make contact' system; dungeons are broken into squares, with all the enemies per square acting as one unit - you make contact, you fight all the enemies on the screen as one. There's room to exploit this to find certain enemies for items, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.


Story-wise it's pretty standard, 'Save the world from a thing, slowly learn more about it' - it nicely frames the gameplay, and has some nice characters; nothing exceptional, but it all tends to work within the game's desired atmosphere. I've only finished one chapter, so it could develop far more than I've seen. I should add that the chapter end wasn't too hard-hitting or notable - indeed, I only noticed because of the achievement popping up!


I'm not sure if it would get worse, but it has a few issues regarding simple grinding to break the flow of combat - once you unlock the battle arena you are immediately treated to a fight against several groups of weak enemies that yield a large amount of skill points, crafting parts and money in one go (enough to power through multiple nodes early on); there is no restriction to the number of times you can do this, so with each character having a Hit-All move, this can be quickly rushed through several times, granting far more rewards than it deserves to...were you patient enough this could probably see a person reaching end-game strength within a couple of hours, potentially. Obviously this isn't that bad, just don't do it - or do it,if that's your bag. Some people would probably call this a bonus feature.


Graphically it is what it is, nothing really goes against the visual style you see. Some breaks and odd parts in various dungeons, but really nothing bad enough to warrant discrediting the game for it.


Waffle waffle etc etc. It will at most be a few £s, and it's definitely worth it if the above sounds acceptable to you - I got it for 99p in a sale, definitely glad I gave it a shot; for me, it rivals a few chart J-RPGs I've bought in the past. It does the genre proud, at a time when it's mostly fading into obscurity.

This game, there's so much I have to say about this game....

Pros:
- all leveling comes through a sp grid, and you gain sp based on what enemies you fight
- even though each of your main characters have a different sp grid setup so they try and make them fall into preset roles, everyone can eventually learn anything which allows for some extreme versatility
- All four characters have rather deep personas you learn about through the game, thus making you learn about them seem fun.
- The dialogue in this game is a BLAST I was laughing uproariously at many points in this game
- You can name your characters, this might not seem like much but I named my main character Doofus, insanity ensued.
- Some of your party members leave at certain points in the game (CHAP 4 DARN YOU!), but when they return any additional sp you have gained in battles they obtain as well, meaning no one is left behind.
- Although most bosses are immune to some status effects, nearly every boss is susceptible to at least one status effect or another, often times they are only resistant meaning hitting them enough times allow said status to stick
- There's a very nice difficulty curve in this game, it steadily increases through the game, and the bosses get harder as you go along, of course I don't find any of them very challenging until you get to the boss of chp4 
- the game is fun to go through, there's no point where the story really drags, and everything is genuinely fun to go through, and since you can freely travel the world map once you complete an area you can go back and heal once you beat each area if you desire to.

Cons:
- This is a nitpick for me but, one of your characters is a demon, I don't like that
- You have both physical, and elemental attacks in this game, though it becomes obvious very early on that elemental attacks are MUCH more effective than any physical attacks are.

- Despite each characters originality they all in battle will eventually fall into a 'jack of all trades' category

17581670.review:
I don't even know where to begin with this game. It was amazing when I played it on newgrounds and it's even better now. Crystal Story 2 is the kind of game which you might consider "casual fan" before realising you've invested hours upon hours of playing it and trying to get everything. It's the type of game that beats all odds and exceeds your expectations.


 Story: ++++

The story of Crystal Story 2 isn't anything really unique. You've probably seen it before. Unlikely hero in a strange world finds a party of friends, travels the world and beats the ultimate evil. However, the developer acknowledges this and instead of trying to glorify it, he has fun with it, plays with various cliches and over-used tropes and ends up creating a very entertaining, fun story which...miraculously...even manages to surprise you at various points in the game. I won't give anything away but get ready to laugh, cry and go "Awww" in the most unique "cliche" story you will ever experience.


 Characters: ++++

Not much can be said about the characters. They're your usual teen party that saves the world from the evil demon. You have the spiky haired, half-dragon protagonist, the over-excited rogue/thief, the broody emo and the over-emotional teenage girl. Throughout the game, you'll meet other characters as well, some of which were in the original crystal story as well. If you play that first, they're fun to run into and talk to, albeit, somewhat weak in combat.
Although each of the main characters fills a specific anime trope, they all have debt and never feel hollow or uninteresting. Each time you stop in a town, you get to speak with them in the inn and explore their personalities a little more.
The game takes itself seriously but not TOO seriously. The characters perfectly reflect this.

However, their team dynamic is the real focus here. These characters would be decent at best if solo. But seeing their interactions together is what makes this party so interesting. You can see they developr real relationships and have fun together. Their relationship is better developed than that of many high-budget JRPG parties out there.

There's also a robot side-kick you unlock after reaching Crystalia, the capital of the world. However, he never leaves Crystalia so he's as good as gone after you leave the place. His purpose is to tell jokes and change the character names. The jokes are puns. Hear at your own risk.


 Gameplay: +++++

The gameplay is rather typical. Turn based combat, various classes to pick for your characters, explorable environments and a variety of mini-games to play through-out the game. And yet, as simple as that might seem, it actually becomes rather complex and fun once you unlock your second class.
The characters get stronger as you play by acquiring SP (skill points) through combat and then spending them. This replaces the typical level system with a much better and way more fun class system. Each class has 5 levels and each level has a pre-set amount of stat spheres you can unlock with SP to make each character stronger. When you reach the final stat sphere, you unlock a secondary level 1 class. This repeats until you max out 2 level 5 classes where you can choose a 3rd level 1 class. This however happens either very late into the game or with a lot of farming so you won't ever be overpowered unless you are ready to grind.

In addition to the main quests, the game offers a variety of side-quests and mini-games as well. You can collect trading cards in the world and then play a rather addictive card-game at an inn. You can look for loot in fishing ponds. You can do bounty hunts before and after the games final boss. You can participate in various arena battles and get stronger. Or you can just shit back and enjoy the music from the inn's jukebox. There's no rush. The game makes it obvious it wants you to have fun and decide for yourself how you want to progress and when.

*(Note: For any fans of the thief class, you should know that stealing in this game is also very rewarding. Some could argue it's actually essential to unlock everything but you can go through the game without worrying about it.)


 Customization: +++++

The game has a very rich customization system.
You have a weapon slot and 3 armor slots (which are practically for both armor and accessories). You unlock the armor slots as the game progresses.
While this is straight-forward enough, the real focus of this system is actually in the upgrade system of your equipment. You can upgrade literary everything.
All items have levels and stages. Most start at stage 1, level 1. You upgrade their levels using money and scrap metal (which you can either buy, steal or find by killing enemies). Then, you'll be prompted to upgrade their stage using a crystal. So now you have an item stage 2, level 1 and you can upgrade it further.
This system is flawlessly designed.  Your items will never feel useless or weak because you can always upgrade them.

In addition to this, there's also an in-depth crafting system. What this means is that you can use your loot to create even better loot. Essentially, you'll be using it to craft your starting gear into stronger gear. So instead of using 2 slots, one for an MP trinket and another for an HP trinket, you'll combine them into 1 item and free 1 slot.
Other than equipment, you can also craft items such as potions, elixirs and bombs. This process, however, becomes almost mechanical after a while since you'll never run out of the ingredients required for these items.


 World: +++++

The world is actually surprisingly large and rich considering the price of the game. You have a variety of towns, dungeons, secret locations etc. and you'll never feel like they're repeating themselves. There's also a lot of end-game dungeons which are practically the climax of the game. Even more so than the final boss. And, of course, there's an extra chapter after the main storyline ends which adds even more to an already surprisingly large game. I honestly can't believe how rich and well-made this RPG is.
The overworld is also well designed and feels nostalgic to old school RPGs.

One thing you might consider a drawback is that the towns feel practically the same. A hand-drawn background of whichever city you're in and a menu with which you can access the inn, the shop etc.
Once you reach Crystalia, the inn is replaced by a palace but that's about it.
The real difference between them is that later towns have more items available in the stores. However, after a point you won't actually care about that. Eventually you'll return to Crystalia every time since it's the only town that has your robot sidekick in it as well as scrap metal for sale. The arena and the card battles are all the same throughout all towns. The only reason to return to older towns would be to complete the bounty hunts and after that, you'll not be seeing them again.

Not much else can be said about the world. It's vast, it's fun to explore, it feels great to be in it.


 Soundtrack: +++++

The soundtrack fits this game perfectly. It has everything. It's reminiscent of the bit era of music but it goes beyond that.
Each area has a unique track to go with it both in the exploration and in the combat segments. This means that you'll never get bored, hearing the same track over and over again.
There's also specific themes that are made solely for the story segments.

In addition to all this, you can also use the jukebox present in every inn and listen to whichever track you wish (only requirment is that you've progressed far enough in the story).

Honestly, this is the type of effort I wasn't even expecting from a game of this price. The music is practically a selling point in and of itself.


 Achievements: +++


Nothing noteworthy here. The achievements aren't anything I looked forward to earning. Most of them practically happen as you play the game. By the end of it, you'll already have most of them and you still w

Un RPG de la vieja escuela que me ha sorprendido muy gratamente ^^

Que no te engañen sus graficos, quizás no sean su punto fuerte, pero son agradables de ver y fueron hechos todos por solo una persona, no solo graficos, sino sonido, programación...

Su sistema de combate recuerda mucho a Final Fantasy X y a la saga Grandia, con la barra por turnos que te indica aproximadamente el orden de los participantes en la batalla y cuanto tardaras en volver a acxtuar dependiendo de la acción que hagas, como atacar o realizar conjuros

El sistema de 'niveles' no existe como tal, en cambio ganamos puntos de Habildiad que distribuir por un tablero de esferas, que recuerda mucho a Final Fantasy XIII, pero con el aliciente que puedes eleguir que 'camino' tomar cada personaje, siendo así más Guerrero, Ladrón o Curandero entre otros

Todo esto aderezado por muchos minijuegos para 'desconectar' de tanto combate, en concreto:

[list]
    [*]Juego de Cartas
    [*]Pesca
    [*]Alinear Gemas
    [*]Hackear Cofres
    [*]Tower Defense
    [*]Snowboard
[/list]

Podría seguir con otras de sus virtudes, como su sistema de mejora de armas y accesorios, más de 30 misiones secundarias, Arena de Batalla, Superjefes secretos...

Como contra hay que decir que está en Inglés, pero aunque el juego tiene sus historia con dialogos, tampoco es muy dificil de comprender, ya que el juego te marca la misión principal con una exclamación amarilla y las secundarias en azul

Por último, su duración es muy buena, la historia principal me duró unas 15 horas, no siendo extremadamente difícil, pero luego el Postgame me dio otras 15 horas y una dificultad muy alta en algunos casos, 'obligandote a llevar a tus personajes a sus limites de fuerza y a ti a buscar la manera de vencerles y por solo 2,99€, la relación calidad/precio es un gran punto a su favor

90/100

16350763.review:
Crystal Story II jest to gra typu turn-based RPG, w której to wcielamy się w rolę bohatera Dragona, którego celem jest pokonanie złej wiedźmy i ocalenie świata. Fabuła sama w sobie nie jest rozbudowana, zazwyczaj następuje przy dostaniu się do nowych lokacji lub spotykaniu ważniejszych postaci. Na swojej drodze szukamy przyjaciół, którzy pomogą nam przetrwać podczas eksploracji pewnych terenów. Dodam, że ta pomoc jest niezwykle przydatna, ponieważ na późniejszych poziomach, bardzo ciężko jest przejść daną strefę.

[b]Zalety:[/b]
+ pierwszą zaletą, jaką można przytoczyć to na pewno to, że gra jest banalnie prosta; z czasem staje sie trudniejsza (w razie potrzeby mamy do dyspozycji samouczek),
+ po osiągnięciu pewnego etapu w grze, mamy do dyspozycji 4 postacie (można je ulepszać pod względem umiejętności jakimi mają dysponować np. elemental effect najlepiej połączyć z heal helper; bardzo ważne jest dopasowywać umiejętności do postaci, tak by móc je wykorzystać i nie stracić żadnego 'pionka' w walce),
+ możliwość odnowienia postaci w bezpiecznych punktach - miastach, za jedyne 50golda, po jakimś czasie trudno bedzie zauważyć straty,
+ dodatkowo w 'save place' można odbierać questy z bounty board, w celu zyskania dodatkowych nagród i umiejętności (zazwyczaj to walki z bossem), można dołączyć do trybu walk na arenie - gdzie mamy określonych przeciwników - gangi, mocniejsze stwory, albo sami szefowie; można zarówno wytwarzać nowe itemy z surowców znalezionych, jak ulepszać nasze wyposażenie - bronie, zbroje, amulety,
+ w każdym momencie gry możemy ręcznie zapisać postęp gry,
+ defense mode - ustawianie wzorówkolorów w jednej linii, liczące conajmniej 3 takie elementy, dzięki temu zyskujemy atak (należy dodać, że im wolniej atakujemy przez zbijanie segmentów, tym więcej pomocników może wysłać defense boss),
+ można łowić ryby - zaletą tego jest iż można złowić różne typy ryb, w tym rzadkie i każda z nich ma swoje unikalne właściwości, które pomogą nam czy to podczas walki czy podczas przeprawy po lochach,
+ card battle mode - chyba najtrudniejszy mod w tej grze, w którym to walczymy z komputerowym przeciwnikiem (Jedni by powiedzieli komputer? banał. Nic bardziej mylnego.) - podczas walki mamy do dyspozycji zebrane karty podczas pokonywania stworów losowo nam dropią różne karty, mamy do dyspozycji 4 efekty żywiołów (ogień, mróz, pioruny oraz ziemia), nalezy je wykorzystać w odpowiedni sposób, gdyż:
walka zawiera 2 lub 3 rundy, w zalezności od wyniku podczas walki (kończy się gdy 1 z graczy uzyskuje 2 wygrane), możemy wybrać tylko 5 kart (tutaj najlepszym wyborem nie są pośrednie karty, lecz takie które mają wysoki atak i obrone (dodam, że trzeba to wykorzystać podczas walki, gdyż losowo mamy przydzielane strony - defender lub attacker), dodatkowo żeby nie było za pięknie, przeciwnik może anulować podwojoną punktacje z żywiołów, przez danie drugiej karty z innym żywiołem (to samo działa w drugą stronę, my też możemy tak zrobić) - ryzyko w tym jedno, gdy jedna ze stron załóżmy, że nie ma danego żywiołu do bonusu i da inny, a my chcąc mu pokrzyżować szyki, możemy mu zwiększyć atak lub obronę dwukrotnie, także należy niezmiernie uważać i obserwować grę (wszystko wyjdzie z czasem),
+ snowboard - zdawałoby sie, że kilka drzew na pewnych odcinkach nic nam nie zrobi, oczywiście nic bardziej mylnego (im więcej unikamy, tym większą prędkość zyskujemy i nie jesteśmy potem już w stanie przewidzieć lokacje 'progu zwalniającego'), mod w sam raz do relaksu,
+ mercenary defense (do dyspozycji mamy na początek 3 postacie - wojownik, mag oraz rycerz - oczywiście każdy ma odpowiednią cenę, na start zyskujemy odpowiednią kwotę i wraz z zabijaniem kolejnych przeciwników zyskujemy parę golda na postawienie następnych obrońców) - ten mod polega na odpowiednim dobraniu postaci i obronie prawej strony planszy,
+ podczas naszej podróży cały czas mamy dostęp do - plecaka (czyli itemy, umiejętności postaci itp.), ustawień gry, zapisu gry, uproszczonej mapy,
+ soundtrack całkiem przyjemny, lecz nie spektakularny, nadaje odpowiedni klimacik.

Grę oceniam bardzo pozytywnie, gdyż nie jest bardzo wymagająca (w każdej chwili można się zrelaksować), można na swojej drodze wybrać odpowiednie tryby gry i między nimi sie przełaczać z pewnych miejsc, podróżowanie po mapie jest całkowicie bezpieczne, możliwość poruszania się na klawiaturze (oraz używania całej palety wyborów) lub też dla leniwych za pomocą samej myszki.
P.S. Nie będę opisywać krótko fabuły, ponieważ zbytnio mnie ona nie interesuje. Jeżeli lubisz proste gry, typu turn-based, to polecam.

Ocena ogólna gry [b]Crystal Story II[/b] - 8/10 ( 8 - Very Good ).

Crystal Story 2 is pretty much a lightweight JRPG. It uses a time based system somewhat similar to child of light that adds obvious flair to a turn based system.

For the price it provides a lot of content, and if you are dedicated to finishing it, you'll likely spend at least 6 hours completing it, on top of the various sidequests.

Story is not usually something I focus too much on in games but it's obvious that a lot of work has gone into the dynamics between the characters and the main tale.

The level up system gives you a lot of choices in how you would build your characters, similarly to FF13 you are able to level up your characters on different classes, giving them some versatility.

I would say the RPG elements are somewhat small, giving you some options to play around with but perfect for someone who doesn't want to get bogged down by a lot of complicated systems.

I enjoyed the game, it's very simple to get into and easy to sink a lot of time in.

15479131.review:
An indie RPG worth every penny. Not a masterpiece in any sense of the word, as the story is mainly just for giggles and give you a flimsy reason to play, but the characters are charming enough, and the inclusion of the first game means there is a lot of content to be had.

Of course, the game wouldn't be worth playing through the content, but CSII is a sublime distillation of RPGs and their battle system. There is always decent difficulty, but the challenges posed against you are always fair, and fair warning is almost always given when you may be going in over your head. You can blow through the main campaign rather quickly, but the real attraction here is the sidequests and the variety of boss monsters you get to face. There is a lot of wonderful loot, and the upgrade trees available through leveling are pure freedom, as you can more or less make each character into whatever strange hybrid of classes you like. This is the first RPG in a long time where I actually looked forward to battles, which is an admitted rarity these days.

If you aren't feeling a classic battle however, there are a handful of well-thought out minigames that break up the potential monotany. All are optional, but they provide a charming time and show just how much love the developer has for this game. There's a charming couple takes on match 3 gameplay just because, and there's a surprisingly thought out card game that you can check out whenever you want. Neither are perfect, but the card game in particular is deceptively intellegent in its execution, but simple enough to pick up. Honestly, if it was to ever be fleshed out more, it could make a decent standalone, though a bit threadbare at the moment. 

Crystal Story II is definitely a love letter. Flawed, fun, and evidence of a work of passion, its sense of humor and immense amount of content only began to wear on me around the 50 hour mark, and is a game I plan on finishing to completion somewhere down the road. A great addition to anyone's library to see just how great an indie RPG can be.

《Crystal Story II》是一款從程式設計、關卡編程、圖像繪製全都由一人包辦的獨立製作角色扮演遊戲，玩家進入遊戲後會發現本作有著濃厚的日式角色扮演遊戲風格，遊戲整體給人的第一印象就像是在重溫《Final Fantasy》系列作品一樣，簡單來說就是王道日式角色扮演遊戲的標準玩法。遊戲中我們所扮演的角色是一名從天界墜落人間的年輕龍族，為了阻止復活的古代魔王達貢摧毀整個世界，主角跟著在旅途上相識的同伴們前往尋找擊敗達貢的方法，經歷苦戰擊敗了神諭者的守衛後，一行人從神諭者口中得知了封印達貢的方法，就是要擊敗四名水晶守護者並取得四顆水晶，封鎖達貢與這個世界的連結。


本作是一款玩起來輕鬆自在的角色扮演遊戲，擔心沒有中文化會看不懂遊戲劇情的玩家不用擔心，本作沒有艱深難懂的故事劇情和原創專有名詞，就算看不懂英文也多少能了解各個角色在作品中所扮演的角色與動機，唯一讓我覺得可惜的就是戰鬥方面稍嫌簡單，少了農怪練等衝裝備的樂趣，除此之外本作對我來說沒有過於明顯的缺點，本作遊戲總時數粗估有十五小時以上，就一款售價不過三美金的獨立小品遊戲來說，這款遊戲帶給消費者的CP值已經超乎想像的高了。如果你玩膩市面上琳瑯滿目的開放世界歐美角色扮演遊戲，或許你會想回到玩法單純有趣日式角色扮演遊戲的懷抱，只需要花費三塊美金就能滿足小小願望，嘗試購買遊玩本作吧！

14803145.review:
If you're anything like me, you had a couple of dollars doing nothing in your Steam account and saw this game pop up either on a sale or just in a general search.

So, the question is... is it worth it?

Crystal Story 2 is a classic-style JRPG about four unlikely heroes that save the... okay, it's not the most original story in the world. But the story unfolds in an entertaining, often humorous way, using cliches seemingly by design. This is evidenced by numerous references to other JRPGs of the past like Final Fantasy Mystic Quest and Breath of Fire. Ultimately, it wears the cliche hat proudly and doesn't try to be anything more.

If you're worried about missing something from the first game, never fear. The game comes complete with the first game included!

The gameplay style of Crystal Story is standard dungeon-crawling fair, either clicking your destination on the screen or WASDing your way around. Encounters are seen on screen and can be avoided a la Earthbound and Chrono Trigger, which is always a welcome addition. In addition to the main storyline, there are also numerous sidequests, often involving chasing down and taking out a boss monster. 

Battles are very fluid and fast-paced in this game. The way it plays out is familiar to anyone who's played a Super NES RPG. On the left side of the screen, you see a meter with every participant on it, rising to the top. Once someone's icon  reaches the top of the meter, they may perform an action. Again, pretty straightforward.

One of the ways this game excels is the level of character customization. While Crystal Story 1 features a mostly linear leveling system dedicated to investing points into learning new skills, Crystal Story 2's character growth system is almost bafflingly expansive. as you progress, you choose one of six class specializations, which opens up an experience tree. For each step on the tree, you invest an increasing number of experience points (or SP, in this game). These tiles can either be a set stat increase, a new ability, or a choice stat increase, in which you can choose which one of two stats to increase. 

This seems complicated, but it truly isn't. The level up system in the game is incredibly intuitive and allows a ton of customization as you make your numbers go up in general. One minor complaint I have about the system, however, is that maybe it's a little TOO precise. Often it feels like more trouble than it's worth opening up the level up screen in the menu and distributing points. It's a slow and often flow-breaking process.

The game also boasts mini games such as a Pipe Dreams style lock-picking game, fishing, and a simple puzzle game which is nonetheless fun in and of itself. Even if the puzzle game in question basically comes free on most smart phones these days. 

As for the music? It's fantastic. The tunes are incredibly memorable and really capture the mood of each scene. Even the simple opening title music has a way of sticking in your head sometimes. 

There's not much to say about the graphics. They're fairly simple in a hand-drawn, anime sort of style. Storylines unfold via stillframe cutscenes which won't light the world on fire. That said, the simple style of the graphics makes it incredibly easy to tell where and what everything is at a glance, making the visuals intuitive and easy on the eyes.

The main storyline of both games are relatively short, but they both have a lot of post-game content to keep you amused.

Ultimately, it boils down to this: did I get 3 dollars worth of entertainment out of this? Definitely. It's a straightforward game with old-school JRPG fans in mind. As such, your enjoyment of this will likely depend on how much you like that style of gaming.

14609771.review:
"I'm going to be the best thief ever! Wait...why are you telling me to steal from every single monster we come across until it's wearing nothing but a loincloth?!" 
"Practice makes perfect."
Still has trouble stealing, even from sleeping enemies.

tl;dr
Anyways, this game is pretty simple for an RPG. It's a turn-based battle system where you can choose between attacking with your weapon, using skills, items, and delaying your turn. 
When you defeat enemies you get SP and most often items/gold, too. You use this SP to buy permanent stat bonuses for your character from their class "line." It's not a branching tree with different skills to choose or anything like that, it's a simple line with occasionally a choice between one stat boost or another and some skills down the line. Once you finish the first class line  you can choose one of the other 6 class lines for "Level 1." So if you were in the Slayer I line you'd get to choose to start Thief, Trickster, Elementalist, Healer, or Guardian I line. After your second line you go up to the 2nd class line so you'd have a choice between Slayer, Guardian, Healer, Elementalist, Trickster, or Thief II. Rinse and repeat. Keep in mind that you're not likely going to have access to the previous skills of any class for a character if you bypass it. So you might want to choose your classes based on which skills that class will get, but you don't get definitions of the skills until you're committed down that class line. 
Don't worry terribly much about stats, because those can be balanced with wearing certain equipment that you can upgrade with Scrap Metal and gems you come across. Scrap metal can be found in battle, stolen from some enemies, or later on purchased in a shop. 

There's more to the game, but I don't want this review to be too long so in short there's a lot to this simple game. You fight monsters, you focus on how you want your character to level up, you can play minigames, fight bosses, grind all you want, and play through the game at your own pace.

14509786.review:
A great JRPG, but only for fans who're fond of the formula. If you do no like Final Fantasy, or others in this genre, then this game is not for you. The game runs smoothly, and the glitches are small, such as dismantling a talisman giving an amethyst instead of a sapphire. The story is present, and not horrible, but able to be skipped. It has a few easter eggs buried in here for those who look, but other than that the story is a basic JRPG one, saving the world from ancient disaster, all that kind of stuff. Playing the original browser game is uneeded to understand the story, although they do make some jokes for those who've played it.

Combat is good, with higher level enemies and bosses needing a fair amount of planning to defeat. Most fights aside from the bosses are able to be avoided, and grinding is not needed until the post-game, if you play your cards right. Plus the battle arena makes grinding coming down to mostly skill. The boss fights are somewhat sub-par to FF standards, but the final boss meets this just fine. For the price, it gives a few hours of enjoyment, plenty of side quest bosses, plus a very challenging post game that really pushes you. 

In terms of tips, the battle area x is great for gaining levels and items post game, plus the stat boost items when using dice. Never use alchemy for equipment other than weapons because you can find those as drops, and use the alchemy deconstruction on the start and last stat boost equipment to rack up as much scrap needed to upgrade weapons as possible. Pray to RNJesus for dice and other rare gear early on, Hold off from buying items in bulk until you get the 25% discount in the water temple, get only what you need until then. The locked blue chests contain rare cards, and the key is hidden in the final level, so don't stress yourself looking how to open it. Save rare items like elixer brews and rocket burst bombs for the final boss fight. Don't be afraid to have a charactor take a different class for a level, as gaining important skills, like buffs, is important since every charactor learns different spells from the same class. Debuffs can fail, and its best to use one with a speedy charactor who can cast them in rapidly to hope one lands on the boss (speedy thief is best for this). Finally, your weapon level decides your ultimate, so you cannot get the achievements for using them until they're level 2 or above, and you unlock the final one at level 4,

14502244.review:
I highly recommend this game for a large number of reasons, but for a short list, here we go:
-Funny/witty dialogue
-Great characters, they each feel unique and have their own personalities
-Level-up system is great, several different branches open for character development
-The sound is phenomenal, i feel each piece fits the situations well
-Gameplay incredibly fun, love the time mechanic as opposed to normal turn based games 
-Expansive game mechanics, such as item creation, other minigames as battles, the arena areas
-Tons of content to play through, im in Ch 1 and i have 5 hours on record XD (Not to say its slow, it actually have a pretty good story plot progression)
-Never found the story to be dull, it was..different in the good way, and it caught my attention
-Incredibly fun if you have a touch-screen laptop as i do, you can just tap everywhere on the screen to move around or attack and such
-Stylized graphics and art design, doesnt have to be top notch HD to be very charming and loveable
-Overall an immensely enjoyable experience

My only problems, which were just nitpicky things that didnt really affect my experience:
-The level-up screen is a bit laggy if you're on the Main Map area, but it's corrected immediately as soon as you go into a town to level-up (My guess is that it just opens a new window and leaves the Main Map animations/environment still loading and active, thus as it tries to do level-up animations it's just doing alot at once)
-You can't delete a save file, which may seem very minor, but i have 1 save i play on and i accidentally saved in another slot, and i dont like seeing the unused save file XD
-When you want to craft a weapon it doesnt tell you the stats of the item, only the effect, but i can see why if you can just upgrade an item with scrap metal you dont necessarily care about stats, only the unique buff


All in all, for 3 bucks or however much this game costs, its a great buy and tons of fun. Im kinda sad i bought this on sale, i wish i could have given the developer(s) the full price XD
9/10

To say the least, this game is an amazing game all around. It's a RPG where you can customize the skills that the characters you have use, and their name. The only customization option missing is changing the clothing of your character, but a lot of RPG games have thrived without that option. It has a skill tree that is very much so comparable to that of Final Fantasy X's but I find it to have more options. The story is fantastic, but you can play Crystal Story II online on various websites, so why pay 2.99$ for it? Well, stated by the creator himself, giving reason to why this is worth the money though you can play it elsewhere for free; [quote=Lan] It has two major updates: the "Deluxe Version" and the "Sword of the Fallen Dragon" update. 


"Sword of the Fallen Dragon"
New chapter (Chapter 6) – Sword of the Fallen Dragon: A new threat has risen. Join the party once again as they investigate the strange mysteries that are happening on the Northern Orc Village.
New side quests -The Curious Thief: A pesky thief has been stealing items from the neighboring towns. The party is hired to catch the thief and return the items that were stolen.
Card Battle: Collect cards and challenge foes to a Card Duel in an all new minigame.
Battle Arena: Monsters line up to challenge your party in battle. Defeat them to earn prizes.
Pet Gifts: Your pet now goes on its own adventure while you are away and will occasionally give you its spare items. Remember to visit it while in town.

"Deluxe Version"
5 New areas and bosses – Five optional new areas and super bosses appear after you've beaten the game to put your party to the ultimate test.
Expanded Armory – Rare armors can now be crafted, and equipment can be dismantled for components.
Exclusive Items – Discover secret items exclusive to the deluxe version throughout the game.
Better Sprites and Audio quality
Increased save slots and improved saving

Also steam features like achievements, cloud saves, trading cards, and no ads.[/quote]

So there are many reasons to buy it as is, plus it comes with the first game as an added bonus. Another good reason to pay the 2.99$ is to support the creator of an amazing game and all of his hard work.
If you care about graphics, then this isn't the game for you because it's graphics are minimalistic and sort of Anime-esque. There are tons of different customization options so if you play through the game, you'll never have the same team twice, unless of course you chose the same options again..

All in all, I'd rate this game an 8/10 because it's not perfect but pretty darn close. 

Good Job "Emmanuel Salva Cruz" I love your game(s) and they have become some of my favorites.

14427943.review:
I wasn't sure what to think when I started this game up. The intro combines Ys 2 and Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Apparently Rita Repulsa has become a J-RPG villain, and it's up to D!ck the dragon to stop her. Along the way, D!ck is joined by Loops the thief, Fu Mario the sheriff, and Razzle the demon. Before you ask, yes I named these characters myself.  Over the course of six chapters, friends are made, monsters are slaughtered, and heroes...heroes...um...heroes do heroic deeds. 

Crystal Story II was conceptualized, designed, programmed,  written, and drawn by one person. He probably also made sandwiches and mixed drinks for the composer and voice-actors. I respect this dude's hustle; the game isn't bad at all either. A lot of what makes CS2 work is in its charm. It'd be easy for me to write up a huge list of J-RPGs and just say "Play all these instead", but CS2 has something special going for it. It's that certain nebulous quality that frustrates reviewers like myself; the kind who think "If this game has this, this, and this, but none of that, then it is awesome." 

Exploration is handled in a very banal manner. The first five chapters stick to genre conventions. There are dungeons, towns, and more dungeons, and the plot is the mortar that holds these bricks together (or was that vice-versa? Analogies are weird). Unfortunately, there's no real exploration to be done. When you reach a new town, you won't find anyone to talk to (unless they're plot-relevant). The dungeons? They're semi-random and divided into several rooms. The layout changes, but treasures stay the same. It's all very bland and dull but here is why I find it appealing: They're short! We all know what to expect when we enter a dungeon: monsters, treasure, and progress. I look at it like this, CS2 strips out the filter so I can focus on what matters. There's no wandering, no interruptions, no "we should camp here for the night" after walking two blocks. Bing bang boom there it is, fight the dungeon boss, and move on. I'll save the epic 3000 floor dungeons for another time.

The battle-system is comparable to Grandia. Never played it? Shame on you. Here's the gist of it: Ally and enemy alike are displayed on a time-line, their turn is next when their icon reaches the top. Simple attacks or item usage causes characters to fall maybe 1/3 of the way down the line, while powerful spells can knock them to the bottom. Status effects such as sleep or stun will keep them from moving up. Early on you'll gain a real appreciation for a high speed stat, because you'll be taking multiple turns for every one the monsters get. Also, by piling on status effects you can keep monsters from acting. For most of the game, this probably won't amount to much. However, expect lots of post-game bosses that'll wreck you for 90-120% of your party's HP if you let them get a turn. For the most part, battles stick to JRPG standards: Regular encounters are a cakewalk, story-bosses expect you to pay a little attention, optional fights demand that you know what you're doing.

Leveling up is similar to FF13. There are multiple classes, each with their own abilities and stat-bonuses. Eventually all four characters will learn every ability, and you decide on who nukes and heals, who buffs & nerfs, and who stabs & slices. You'll want to specialize to get the most out of every turn. Also you can accumulate a ton of scrap to strengthen your favorite weapons and accessories. The system is basic, but well-done. 

Unlike far too many RPGs, Crystal Story II doesn't have a thousand flowery names for every item, spell, and monster you come across. A Healing Potion isn't called a Diffluebo, the Skeletons aren't Sticzis, and you don't cast Firagrammo, you cast Fire II. There are some out there who might cry foul at this, and make up some junk like "names = world-building". There is a time and a place for all of that, and you'll find neither in this game. This is something that I'm thankful for. It makes for an easier game to just pick up and play, since I don't have to quickscan a FAQ just to remind myself of which healing spell is which.

As the store page will tell you, CS2 has a handful of minigames:
-Match three 
-Tower defense
-Card game
-Snowboarding
-Hacking (?!?)

They're not astonishing in quality, and you'll find better versions in other games (possibly even other JRPGs), but they're amusing diversions. I never fussed with Plants Vs Zombies or any similar game, so learning and subsequently completing the tower defense mini-game was pretty entertaining. I could do without the snowboarding though, blech.

Honestly, I'm shocked that I enjoyed Crystal Story 2 as much as I did. I was so quick to write it off at any moment, but a crapton of those moments came together to form 20+ hours. It doesn't hit the highs of other JRPGs, but it also doesn't have any of the lows. While I didn't get 3 hours of tremendous 1080P CGI cutscenes featuring D!ck the Dragon, I also didn't have to put up with 15+ hours of tortuous nonsense because some guy with spectacular hair and a goofy sword decided to take the scenic route. Aside from one short incident, everyone in your party are bros to the end. There's no shouting matches, and Fu Mario doesn't run away while crying "WHY IS RITA SO MEEEEEAAAAANNNNN?!?"

If you want a quaint little adventure this is a safe purchase.
If you love grinding (and who doesn't?!) this is a very safe purchase.

I wasn't sure what I was looking for when I got this game, but I guess everything worked out. 
YMMV

Holy smokes I never even noticed. The first Crystal Story is included as well. I'll have to give it a go sometime.


BTW: What's wrong with saying D!ck? Is it so wrong to be named D!ck? What if I wanted to review Mary Poppins on Steam? I imagine that'd be pretty hard if I can't talk about D!ck Van Dyke.

14396726.review:
Pros:
-Open level up system that feels constantly rewarding
-Lots of side quests
-Solid, if simple, battle system
-Light and humorous. While rarely laugh out loud funny, you'll probably smile a little. 
-Great music

Cons
-The graphics are... less than stellar
-Dungeons are repetitive and can get dull
-Nothing new to see here

Don't let the Newgrounds era flash looking graphics throw you off, this game is actually quite a gem. The story is light and fairly predictable, but keeps your interest with quirky characters that do a good job both paying homage to and flipping cliche conventions. While not the most well-rounded around, the main cast is generally likable (Especially Lina, she's adorable and spunky without being overbearing or annoying) and the NPC's form an oddball cast that--while not terribly memorable--serve the purpose of keeping you entertained. 

This is very much a game intended to appeal only to fans of the genre looking for a quick, light revisit to the old JRPG glory days. In that, it delivers wonderfully. Fans of old-school Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest and the like will find all of this wonderfully familiar, and should have absolutely no trouble jumping right in. For some, the 'been there, done that' aspect of it might be a turn off, but for me, it was exactly what I was looking for. A fun, accessible turn-based battle system, and a slightly unconventional level up system (you apply your points directly to learning skills or gaining ability points, rather than it happening automatically, with new paths unlocking once each is complete--it's basically a stripped down version of Final Fantasy X's Sphere Grid), combined with the ability to both improve your equipment, and forge new adds much needed depth, and gives the game a spot on balance between easily accessible and customizable. 

It's not breaking any new ground, but it's not really aiming to. If you're looking for a fun look back at the great JRPG's of the past, you could do much worse than this little fling.

2 hours into the game and I'm already hooked. The art is well drawn, the animation is decent and the gameplay is great. 

Turn based combat can be quite the sticky thing, do it wrong and you have a boring game that's annoying to play. Do it right and you've got players enthralled and eager to beat the next boss. Crystal Story II has managed that amazingly well. Speed intergrates smoothly into the play and there's a handy bar to the left displaying when each character has his/her turn.

The weakest part of the game so far has been the story. It seems to be the old tired and true "return the crystals" routine, although admittedly I am (as of wrting this) only two hours into the game and not entirely sure if that is the main goal here. The plot isn't forced down your throat either, it's their enough to give you a drive in the game and the characters so far are genuinly interesting. It's a nice touch to be able to name them yourself too.

If you like RPG based games, or just want a fun way to spend some time, definitely try this out.

I know it says I haven't played this game for long, but trust me, I played at least 30 hours of this game of Kongregate before it came on Steam. And that's just assuming a low number because I don't know how high my actual playtime is.

Crystal Story II is just a simple, turn-based RPG with a very light-hearted and nonsensical story. Altogether, that's what the game boils down to.

Play it, however, and you'll find an intriguing battle system with four fully customizable characters and a plethora of equipment to buy and spells to learn.

The story really isn't anything groundbreaking, but come on, it was orignally a made-for-free flash game. For that standard, the story is far from awful and will actually keep you curious for a good bit.

Accompanying the battle system is an INCREDIBLE soundtrack that seriously blew me away, even on the flash websites. Seriously, this guy needs a medal for his sound design, and you can listen to the whole OST in game once you hear each song once in game.

There is also voice acting (some, most of the game is told in text), which, while in my opinion quite good in battle, lacks a little professonalism in some of the cutscenes.

With a wealth of bonus content and games, the original crystal story (so you can see how much the author improved, that's honestly the only reason to play it), and a great package, seriously, jtus get this game and support guys like this. He has wonderful ideas, and even though I don't like paying for games all that much, the SECOND i saw this was available, I bought it. No regrets. ^^
